course.subject: HART
course.name: Introduction to Graphic Design
course.description: Graphic design is the art of communication through the combination of images and words into a unified form to convey a clear message to an audience. Common uses of graphic design include logos, signs, publications, posters, print advertisements, product packaging and web sites, etc. This course aims to introduce students to what graphic design is and the design process. The basic elements, principles and process of graphic design will be explored and illustrated by works of famous graphic designers. Through the problem-solving approach, students will learn how to apply the design basics to create graphic design solutions. Although the course is focused on printed matter, design for the screen such as web sites will be discussed. Class time is devoted to lectures, exercises, and critiques where students are asked to evaluate each other’s work. Such evaluations are very important in the development of analytical thinking and communication proficiency.

I think the B range is infinitely large.

reviews.comment_workload:
1. Participation marks (+ impression marks):
one small assignment per week eg. drawing different kinds of lines, designing a small logo, making a business card, etc.

2. ***Most essential***:
You will have to hand in the lag log with all your work so far at the end of the course. You have to add comments/ what you have learnt from the class into the lag log.
（The earlier you start to do, the easier it is. ）

3. Group project: making a poster for the HKUST library
You will have about 4-6 lessons for the poster so you have plenty of time.

1.參與分（＋印象分）：
你必須交出一個小任務，比如繪製不同類型的線條，設計小徽標，製作名片等。

2. ***最重要的***：
到目前為止，在課程結束時，您將不得不提交所有工作整合的日誌，將從課程中學到的內容添加其中。
（越早開始做，越容易）

3. 小組項目：為科大圖書館製作海報

reviews.author: iamwildcat
reviews.title: Easy intro to Graphic Design
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Graphic Design principles.
Usage of points, lines, shapes, colours etc
Elements of contrast, focus, repetition & spacing.
Small introduction to typography and layout design.
Final project to implement all that you've learned into a poster design for a campaign (you'll need to present your initial idea, progress presentation, make the poster itself, submit a group project report and record all you've done in a logbook)
Also includes software workshop on Photoshop and Illustrator, not compulsory if you already know them.
There is also a lesson where a guest speaker, who is himself a graphic designer, came and shared his experience in working in the field, giving us a glimpse of how graphic design works in real life.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Alice is a very nice tutor. Her tone is comfortable and at the same time encouraging to students.
She is very experienced in the field of Design Education and has been affiliated to HKPU Design School for quite some time.
Since the class is small, she is always willing to give us useful comments on our draft designs. Some may find it critical and nitpicking, but in the field of Design, taking critics is a major part of your job, so get used to it.
reviews.comment_grading:
Easiest A range in my life.
Mind you, I do possess drawing and design background,
and I do have a passion in pursuing graphic design as a career.
Spend more time polishing your products and it will be worth it.
Final Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
This should have been a 3-credit course, that's all I'm going to say.
Every week we have a small assignment, namely information research, typography design, poster revamp, name cards etc.
You'll have to present your drawing in front of class every week.
And put them into a logbook.
The logbook is essentially all things you've done in the course, plus personal reflections and comments.
The group project accounts for a huge part of the course and grades. Things you'll need to do
- Initial idea generation.
- Present ideas in mind map (specific form)
- Progress presentation
- Make the poster itself
- Presentation on final poster
- Give comments on other's poster
- Submit a group project report
- Record all stuff you've done on to logbook
**TAKES A LOT OF TIME***

reviews.author: Charmian
reviews.title: Pretty interesting course but a little bit of a let-down
reviews.comment_content: I entered this course because I thought I would have been able to learn more computer-related design skills such as Adobe Photoshop and other design tools. Surprisingly, it was mostly about theories in graphic design and the only time we got to learn design programs (Adobe Photoshop and Illustrator) were in 3 supplementary workshops after the classes. So if you are looking for a class to learn more about design programs, this probably isn't the course for you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Alice overall is an okay instructor, but be prepared to jot down notes in this class, because her slides are picture-heavy and thus she says she cannot give it to us due to the pictures' copyrights.

Personally I feel she's a little forceful on opinions when this is supposed to be a more 'creative' class and that she might be prejudiced to those who can draw reasonably well. She does tend to miss people out during discussions and end discussions so it's probably better to be more proactive in discussions as it seems to affect class participation grades greatly.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is based on class participation, your logbook, weekly assignments and of course, the group project. Heavy percentage on the group project and weekly assignments.
reviews.comment_workload:
There's always a take-home assignment after class every week, which is graded and is normally used for class discussion.

A logbook is also required in this class, where you chart down your design ideas, reflections and assignments as well as project progress. This does take some time to do so it's recommended that you update it weekly.

There is also the class project, in which when I took it was to design a poster to encourage more reading in the UST library. This will be done over the entire semester in groups of 3-4 people.

So it's considerably pretty heavy workload although no midterms or finals for a 1-credit course.
